description:
The GEODE sequence has five activities.

In this module, you will consider the question: what will Earth look like in 500 million years? You will use data from Earth and models of a fictional planet to explore plate tectonics.

This GEODE sequence was last changed on August 9, 2018.

Thumbnail image: Screenshot of Tectonic Explorer geodynamic model
display_title: What will Earth look like in 500 million years?
title: 2018-2019 GEODE Module "What will Earth look like in 500 million years?" (v1)

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore how Earth changed over the past 500 million years as a way to start to understand how Earth will change in the future.

You will explore paleogeographic maps to see how Earth looked in the past. You will make predictions about how Earth might look in 500 million years.

Finally, you will use Seismic Explorer, a data model, to explore the locations of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on present-day Earth. You will make hypotheses about why the earthquakes and volcanic eruptions have happened where they have.

Thumbnail image: Palogeographic Maps by C.R. Scotese, © 2013, PALEOMAP Project, (www.scotese.com)
activities.name: How did Earth change in the past?

pages.name: How did Earth look in the past?
pages.text:
What will Earth look like in 500 million years?

Earth is approximately 4.5 billion years old (4,500 million years). Certainly, Earth has changed since it was formed from hot molten dust. The surface has cooled, and life now exists on the planet. Is Earth still changing, and how much is it changing? To answer the question of how Earth might look in the future, it helps to understand how Earth changed in the past.

How do we know what Earth looked in the past?

Geoscientists study Earth's rocks and surface to figure out what Earth looked like in the past. Their data have been used to construct paleogeographic maps, maps that show the history of Earth's geography. These maps illustrate the locations of Earth's continents and oceans over hundreds of millions of years.

The slideshow below shows paleogeographic maps for 15 times in Earth's history, from today (0 Ma) to 514 million years ago (Ma or mya).

Click through the slideshow to see how Earth's surface changed over the past 514 million years. Note the locations of landmasses throughout the series. Note also the location of oceans and seas over the time sequence.

embeddable.prompt:
Look at the shape and locations of continents over time.

Describe how the continents have changed over the past 514 million years.
Describe how the shapes of the oceans changed over the past 514 million years.

pages.name: How will Earth look in the future?

embeddable.prompt: Based on how Earth has changed over the past 514 million years, explain how you think it will look 500 million years in the future.
What evidence do you have for your prediction?
How do you think this change will happen?
What evidence do you think you need to answer this question?

pages.name: What is happening on Earth today?
pages.text:
Now that you have explored Earth's past and thought about what might be in its future, it's time to look at Earth's present. You will use the Seismic Explorer model to investigate some information about Earth's recent history.

In this model, you can explore the locations of earthquakes that have occurred since 1980 and volcanic eruptions that have happened over the past ~6,400 years.

Both earthquakes and volcanoes are available in the model. To show earthquakes, press the Play button. The earthquakes will be displayed in the map in the order in which they occurred. Use the timeline to see the dates on which earthquakes occurred.

To hide earthquake or volcano data so that you can focus on one at a time, click on the Data type menu and uncheck the feature that you don't want to see. Check the box to show the feature again.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the patterns that you notice in the locations of earthquakes since 1980.
Describe the patterns that you notice in the locations of active volcanoes.
Why do you think the earthquakes and volcanoes are located where they are?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Do you think that the present-day pattern of earthquakes and volcanoes on Earth is related to Earth's history?
Explain why you think the present-day patterns of earthquakes and volcanoes are (or are not) related to Earth's history.
How long do you think it takes for an earthquake to occur?
How long do you think it takes for a volcano to erupt?
How long do you think it takes a volcano (or other mountains) to form?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore how some features on Earth were created by plate interactions. You will use Tectonic Explorer to model the formation of the features.

Thumbnail image: Andes Mountains – Punta Arenas. NASA - Public Domain, Link
activities.name: How did Earth's features form? (Part 1)

pages.name: Explaining how Earth's features formed
pages.text:
In Activity 1, you saw paleogeographic maps that showed how Earth's surface has changed over the past 514 million years. You also saw Seismic Explorer, which showed the locations of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on Earth over the more recent past.

Geoscientists use elevation, earthquake, and volcano data to investigate the processes that resulted in many of the geological features that we can see on Earth today.

In this activity, you will explore patterns of landforms, earthquakes, and volcanoes to explain why Earth's surface changed in the past and will continue to change in the future.

The image below shows a panoramic view of the Himalayas, a mountain range north of India.

embeddable.caption: Panoramic view of Mount Everest or Chomolungma from the north inside Tibet.
embeddable.credit: By W. Mason Fuller (talk · contribs) of Boise, Idaho. http://www.masonfuller.com - Transferred from en.wikipedia to Commons., Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=6627289

pages.name: How did the Himalayan Mountains form?
pages.text:
The Himalayan mountain range, home of Mount Everest, are located between India and Asia. How did these large mountains form?

In the case study on this page, you will:

Collect elevation data about elevation differences in the areas around the Himalayan mountain range from a geographic profile.

Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies in the Himalayan mountain range from Seismic Explorer.

Set up a model in Tectonic Explorer to show how the Himalayan mountain range formed.

Develop a scientific argument about how the Tectonic Explorer model explains the formation of the Himalayan mountain range.

 


By W. Mason Fuller (talk · contribs) of Boise, Idaho. http://www.masonfuller.com - Transferred from en.wikipedia to Commons., Public Domain

embeddable.content:
Collect elevation data.

The geographic profile provides information about the land elevation along the profile line (from point A to point B in the map). The graph shows the elevation above sea level (measured in meters) along that line.

embeddable.hint: The distance is shown on the x-axis of the graph.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
The graph shows the elevation along the line from point A to point B.

From point A on the map, how far away is the start of the mountains?

choices.prompt: Where does the graph show the elevation start to increase?
Correct! The elevation starts to rise at 1000 km from point A.
Where does the graph show the elevation start to increase?

embeddable.hint: Look at the elevation data on the y-axis.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the geographic profile graph, what is the highest elevation along this profile line?

choices.prompt: Correct! The highest elevation on this profile line is 6000 m.
Are you sure? This is the distance of the highest elevation from point A, but it is not the highest elevation. Look at the y-axis for the elevation.
Are you sure? This is the length of the profile line, not the highest elevation. Look at the y-axis for the elevation.
Are you sure? Look at the y-axis to see the units used to measure elevation.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the change in elevation from Point A to Point B along the profile line.

embeddable.content:
Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies.

The Seismic Explorer model is zoomed in to the same area.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

The Seismic Explorer map type is called a relief map. This type of map shows the elevations of land with colors.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the relief map colors in Seismic Explorer and the geographic profile, which color in the relief map shows the highest elevations?

choices.prompt: The blue colors are found in areas that have water. These are not the highest elevations on the map.
Do the areas with yellow match up with the highest elevation areas in the geographic profile?
Do the areas with green match up with the highest elevation areas in the geographic profile?
Correct! The dark brown colors, along with some greys, show the highest elevations on the relief map.

embeddable.hint: Look at the key to link earthquake depth to color!
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
Press the Play button to show earthquakes. (You can hide earthquakes by unchecking the box in the Data type menu.)

Be sure to look at the Key!

Based on Seismic Explorer, how deep are the earthquakes that have occurred in the Himalayas?

Choose all of the answers that apply.

choices.prompt: Some of the earthquakes in the Himalayas occur 0-30 km deep.
Some of the earthquakes in the Himalayas occur 30-100 km deep.
Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
Use the Data type menu to show volcanoes in the Himalayan region.

Based on Seismic Explorer, how many volcanoes are in the Himalayas?

choices.prompt: Correct! There is one volcano shown in the data in Seismic Explorer.
Are you sure? How many volcanoes do you see when you show volcano data in Seismic Explorer?

embeddable.content:
Set up a model.

Use the Tectonic Explorer model to set up experiments to determine how the Himalayan range formed.

The pink line in the model divides the planet into two parts. There is one continent on each part.

You will need to assign forces to try to make a mountain range like the Himalayas. Add forces by drawing arrows on the planet. You can draw one arrow per part. The arrows can be large or small and point in any direction.

Now, try to set up Tectonic Explorer to make a mountain range like the Himalayas.

embeddable.hint: Use the color-coded elevation key in the upper left of the model.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: How tall were the tallest mountains you created in your Tectonic Explorer model?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? This is below sea level!
Didn't you make mountains taller than this?
Those are some pretty tall mountains that you created! How does that elevation compare to the highest elevations in the Himalayas?
Those are some pretty tall mountains that you created! How does that elevation compare to the highest elevations in the Himalayas?

embeddable.content:
You should have noticed a cross section below the planet view in Tectonic Explorer.

The cross-sectional view allows you to see what is happening below the planet's surface. This view can help you think about what might be responsible for the features that you can see on the planet's surface.

If you closed the cross section, reload the model to get it back! Run the model again and watch what happens below the planet's surface.
Develop a scientific argument.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Claim: How did you draw the forces on the two parts of the planet in Tectonic Explorer to create a mountain range like the Himalayas?
Describe how the forces in Tectonic Explorer created a mountain range similar to the Himalayas.

Explanation: Explain how the interaction of the two parts of the planet in Tectonic Explorer, both above and below the surface, could produce a pattern of earthquakes and volcanoes like the data that you observed in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Certainty Rating: How certain are you that your Tectonic Explorer model is a good model of the formation of the Himalayas?

Certainty Rationale: Explain your certainty rating.
Consider the elevations in the geographic profile and earthquake and volcano data from the Himalayan mountain range and the outcomes of your experiments with Tectonic Explorer.

pages.name: Using Tectonic Explorer
pages.text:
Tectonic Explorer is a dynamic model designed to allow you to investigate how features form on a planet's surface. The model divides the planet into parts called tectonic plates. These plates cover surface of the entire planet.

Tectonic Explorer has many features that you will use throughout the rest of this sequence. You've already seen how to assign forces to plates by drawing vectors (those arrows that you drew to make the parts of the planet move in specific directions).

On this page, you'll start to explore more features of Tectonic Explorer so that on the following pages, you can more fully investigate how more Earth features formed.

The Tectonic Explorer model below is set up to show the Planet Wizard. Use the features in the Planet Wizard to create planet setups that answer the questions that follow.

embeddable.prompt: Set up the model to create a mountain range.

embeddable.hint: How did you create mountains on the front side of the planet? Try doing the opposite.
embeddable.prompt: Set up the model to create mountains on the other side of the planet.
Set up the model to create two continents that slide past each other.

embeddable.content:
The cross section tool provides you with a view of what is happening to the plates below the surface.

Watch this video to learn how to make a cross section in Tectonic Explorer.

embeddable.hint: Try changing the densities of the plates. How does that change which plate goes below the other?
embeddable.prompt:
Set up the model so that one oceanic plate goes under another oceanic plate.
In the cross section, circle the plate that is going below the other one.

pages.name: How did the Andes Mountains form?
pages.text:
The map below shows how the Andes Mountains along the entire west coast of South America. The mountains are shown by the dark brown coloration in this relief map.



How did these large mountains form?

In the case study on this page, you will:

Collect elevation data about elevation differences in the areas around the Andean mountain range from a geographic profile.

Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies in the Andean mountain range from Seismic Explorer.

Set up a model in Tectonic Explorer to show how the Andean mountain range formed.

Develop a scientific argument about how the Tectonic Explorer model explains the formation of the Andean mountain range.

By Elemaki - Own work, CC BY 3.0, Link

embeddable.prompt: How do you think the Andes formed?

embeddable.content:
Collect elevation data.

The geographic profile provides information about the land elevation along the profile line (from point A to point B in the map).

The graph's y-axis shows the elevation above and below sea level (measured in meters) along that line. Sea level is at 0 meters.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: At which point on the geographic profile does the land elevation rise to sea level?

choices.prompt: The lowest elevation is shown to occur at 300 km on the profile line.
Correct! The land meets sea level (0 m) at about 380 km from point A.
This is one of the highest elevations above sea level. Where is the elevation just at sea level (0 m)?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: How far from Point A is the lowest point on the geographic profile of the Andes?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? The lowest elevation is lower than -4000 m.
Correct! The lowest elevation on this profile occurs 300 km from Point A.
Are you sure? The lowest elevation is lower than 4000 m.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: On the geographic profile of the Andes, how far is the lowest point from the highest point?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Where is the lowest elevation? Where is the highest elevation?
Are you sure? Where is the lowest elevation? Where is the highest elevation?
Correct! The lowest elevation is at 300 km from Point A, and the highest elevations are at 600-800 km from Point A. This means the lowest elevations are 300-500 km from the highest elevations.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the change in elevation along the profile line.

embeddable.content:
Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies.

The Seismic Explorer model is zoomed in to the same area.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

The Seismic Explorer map type is called a relief map. This type of map shows the elevations of land with colors.

Use the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes in the Andes. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: In the relief map view in Seismic Explorer, what color represents the lowest point of the ocean?

choices.prompt: The light blue colors show the locations of shallower areas.
The blue colors show areas that are deeper than the light blue areas, but they're not the deepest areas!
Correct! The dark blue coloring shows the locations of the oceanic trenches, the lowest spots in the map.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, are there volcanoes in the Andes?

choices.prompt: Correct! There are many volcanoes in the Andes mountains.
Are you sure? Show the volcano data.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the pattern of volcanoes in the Andes.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, how deep are the earthquakes that have occurred in the Andes?
Describe the pattern of earthquakes in the Andes.

embeddable.content:
You can make a cross section in Seismic Explorer to see the pattern of earthquakes below the surface.

Watch the video to learn how to make a cross section in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.prompt:
Make a cross section of the earthquakes in the Andes.
Take a snapshot of your cross section.
Describe the pattern of earthquakes that you can see in the 3D cross section of the Andes.
Based on the data in Seismic Explorer, how long do you think it takes for an earthquake to happen?

embeddable.content:
Set up a model.

Use the Tectonic Explorer model to set up experiments to determine how the Andean range formed.

The model is set up with two plates.

You will need to draw continents, assign forces to each plate, and adjust plate densities to create a feature like the Andes mountains. 

Use the cross section tool to see how the plates interact with each other below the surface.
Develop a scientific argument.

embeddable.prompt: Claim: Describe how the two plates in Tectonic Explorer interacted when you set up the model to form mountains like the Andes.

Explanation: Explain how the interaction of the two plates in Tectonic Explorer, both above and below the surface, could produce a pattern of earthquakes and volcanoes like the data that you observed in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Certainty Rating: How certain are you that your Tectonic Explorer model is a good model of the formation of the Andes?

Certainty Rationale: Explain your certainty rating.

Consider the elevations in the geographic profile and earthquake and volcano data from the Andean mountain range and the outcomes of your experiments with Tectonic Explorer.
Based on your experiments with Tectonic Explorer, how long, in millions of years, does it take for mountains like the Andes to form?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Do you think that earthquakes occur during mountain formation?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.hint: How long does an earthquake take to occur?
embeddable.prompt: Why do you think earthquakes aren't shown in Tectonic Explorer?

pages.name: Density
pages.text:
In your experiments with Tectonic Explorer, you have noticed that when plates move towards each other, one plate goes beneath the other. When one plate goes beneath another, it is said to subduct. What determines which plate subducts beneath the other?

Use the model below to explore this question. Change the densities of the two plates to see how it affects where islands form.

embeddable.hint: Draw a cross section in the model to see which plate goes below (subducts beneath) the other!
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What happens when Plate 1 is denser than Plate 2 as the plates are moving toward each other?

choices.choice: Plate 1 and Plate 2 stay at the same level.

embeddable.content:
You can see examples of density in your daily life. 

 
Think about a log floating on a pond. The wood floats on the water because it is less dense than water. 
 
Think about a helium balloon. The balloon rises up because the helium inside it is less dense than the air outside of it.
 
The picture below shows a density column. 
By PRHaney (Own work) [CC BY-SA 3.0], via Wikimedia Commons

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the picture of the density column, which fluid is denser than the pink object?

choices.prompt: Where is the pink object relative to the red fluid?
Where is the pink object relative to the yellowish fluid?
Yes! The blue fluid is denser than the pink object because the pink object floats on the blue fluid.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
Oceanic crust always subducts (goes beneath) continental crust when plates with these crust types move towards each other.

What does this tell you about the density of the oceanic crust compared to the continental crust?

choices.choice: Oceanic crust is less dense than continental crust.
Oceanic crust is more dense than continental crust.
Oceanic crust has the same density as continental crust.

embeddable.prompt: Explain your answer.

embeddable.hint: Think about the different densities of continental and oceanic crust! Which one is denser?
embeddable.prompt: Why do you think continental crust occurs mostly above sea level while oceanic crust is mostly covered by water?

pages.name: How did the Aleutian Islands form?
pages.text:
The Aleutian Islands form the western-most portion of the United States, stretching from Alaska to Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula. The question for you to answer is, how did this island chain form?

In the case study on this page, you will:

Collect elevation data about elevation differences in the areas around the Aleutian Islands from a geographic profile.

Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies in the Aleutian Islands from Seismic Explorer.

Set up a model in Tectonic Explorer to show how the Aleutian Islands formed.

Develop a scientific argument about how the Tectonic Explorer model explains the formation of the Aleutian Islands.

By Hillebrand Steve, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service - http://www.public-domain-image.com/public-domain-images-pictures-free-stock-photos/nature-landscapes-public-domain-images-pictures/island-public-domain-images-pictures/aleutian-islands-ocean-water.jpg, Public Domain, Link

embeddable.content:
Collect elevation data.

The geographic profile provides information about the land elevation along the profile line (from point A to point B in the map).

The graph's y-axis shows the elevation above and below sea level (measured in meters) along that line. Sea level is at 0 meters.

embeddable.prompt: What geographic feature does the profile show at 500 km from point A?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on the geographic profile, where is the ocean deepest near the Aleutian Islands?

choices.choice: The ocean is deepest 500 km south of the islands.
choices.prompt: In the geographic profile, the island can be found about 500 km from point A. Where is the ocean the deepest?

choices.choice: The ocean is deepest 250 km south of the islands.
choices.prompt: Correct! The ocean is deepest at 250 km from Point A. The island is 500 km from Point A. This means that the deepest part of the ocean is located 250 km from the island.

choices.choice: The ocean is deepest 500 km north of the islands.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? Point A is located south of the islands. Where is the deepest point of the ocean?

choices.choice: The ocean is about the same depth around the islands.
choices.prompt: Are you sure? The profile graph shows many different elevations from Point A to Point B.

embeddable.content:
Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies.

The Seismic Explorer model is zoomed in to the same area.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

The Seismic Explorer map type is called a relief map. This type of map shows the elevations of land with colors.

Use the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes in the Aleutians. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, are there volcanoes in the Aleutians?

choices.prompt: Correct! The Aleutian Islands are a chain of volcanic islands.
Are you sure? Use the Data type menu to show volcanoes in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, how deep are the earthquakes that have occurred in the Aleutians?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!

embeddable.hint: Remember that your cross section line should be drawn perpendicular to the line of earthquakes!
embeddable.prompt:
Make a cross section of the earthquakes that occur in the Aleutians.
Take a snapshot of your cross section.
Describe the pattern of earthquakes that you can see in the 3D cross section.

embeddable.content:
Set up a model.

Use the Tectonic Explorer model to set up experiments to determine how the Aleutians formed.

The model is set up with two plates.

You will need to draw continents, assign forces to each plate, and adjust plate densities to create a feature like the Aleutian Islands. 

Use the cross section tool to see how the plates interact with each other below the surface.
Develop a scientific argument.

embeddable.prompt: Claim: Describe how the two plates in Tectonic Explorer interacted when you set up the model to form an island chain like the Aleutians.

Explanation: Explain how the interaction of the two plates in Tectonic Explorer, both above and below the surface, could produce a pattern of earthquakes and volcanoes like the data that you observed in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Certainty Rating: How certain are you that your Tectonic Explorer model is a good model of the formation of the Aleutian Islands?

Certainty Rationale: Explain your certainty rating.

Consider the elevations in the geographic profile and earthquake and volcano data from the Aleutian Islands and the outcomes of your experiments with Tectonic Explorer.

pages.name: Similarities
pages.text:
In this activity, you explored three areas on Earth – the Himalayas, the Andes, and the Aleutian Islands. Although these areas look different from each other (the Himalayas are a high mountain plateau away from the ocean, the Andes are a mountain chain right along the ocean, and the Aleutians are a island chain in the ocean), they have features in common.

Provided are snapshots of Seismic Explorer, showing the earthquake distribution in each area, in both top-down and cross-sectional views.

Use what you have learned in this activity to fully explain the similarities between these three Earth features.

embeddable.prompt: Describe how the plates move to form features like the Himalayas, the Andes, and the Aleutians.
What is similar about the formation of the Himalayas, the Andes, and the Aleutians? What is different?

In the geographic profile of the Aleutian Islands and in the Andes Mountains, there is an oceanic trench (very low elevation) near to the mountains.
Explain how plate interactions at these locations lead to this combination of surface features.
How is the formation of the Aleutian Islands similar to the formation of the Andes Mountains?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Did volcanoes form during the formation of the Himalayas, Andes, and Aleutian Islands?
Explain your answer.
How can the subsurface 3D pattern of earthquakes be used to show which plate subducts (goes under) beneath the other?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore how some features on Earth were created by plate interactions. You will use Tectonic Explorer to model the formation of the features.

Thumbnail image: Gulf of Eilat, Israel. By Little Savage - Own work, Public Domain, Link
activities.name: How did Earth's features form? (Part 2)

pages.name: Plates on Earth
pages.text:
In Activity 2, you explored three areas on Earth – the Himalayas, the Andes, and the Aleutian Islands. Through your experiments with Tectonic Explorer, you discovered that all of those features were formed as two plates moved towards each other.

The map below shows the plate boundaries on Earth. Each block of color shows a separate plate. The black lines show where the plates meet. The meeting places are called plate boundaries.

The plate boundary between the Nazca plate and the South American plate is highlighted. This is the boundary along which the Andes mountains are located.

embeddable.prompt: Describe how the Nazca plate moves relative to the South American plate. What happens below the surface at that plate boundary?

Based on what happens at the Nazca/South American plate boundary (marked A on the map), describe what you think happens on the other side of the South American plate, where it abuts (touches) the African plate (marked B on the map).

embeddable.credit: Based on United States Geological Survey

pages.name: How did the Red Sea form?
pages.text:
The Red Sea is an inlet of water between Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It formed within the last 50 million years. The image below shows how Africa and Arabia were connected 30 million years ago, compared to today, when the Red Sea lies between Africa and Arabia.

What happened to form the Red Sea? This is the question for you to answer.

In the case study on this page, you will:

Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies in the Red Sea from Seismic Explorer.

Set up a model in Tectonic Explorer to show how the Red Sea formed.

Develop a scientific argument about how the Tectonic Explorer model explains the formation of the Red Sea.

embeddable.content:
Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies.

The Seismic Explorer model is zoomed in to the same area.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view.

The Seismic Explorer map type is called a relief map. This type of map shows the elevations of land with colors.

Use the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes in the Red Sea. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, are there volcanoes in the Red Sea region?

choices.prompt: Correct! There are volcanoes along the west side of the Red Sea, as well as at the southeastern side.
Are you sure? Use the Data type menu to show volcanoes in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, how deep are the majority of earthquakes that have occurred near the Red Sea?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!
Are you sure? Check the key!

embeddable.content:
Set up a model.

Use the Tectonic Explorer model to set up experiments to determine how the Red Sea formed.

The model is set up with two plates.

You will need to draw continents, assign forces to each plate, and adjust plate densities to create a feature like the Red Sea.

Use the cross section tool to see how the plates interact with each other below the surface.

embeddable.prompt:
Take a snapshot of your Tectonic Explorer model showing the formation of a feature like the Red Sea.

Make sure that your snapshot includes the cross section view!
Describe where you placed continents in this model to create a feature like the Red Sea.

embeddable.content: Develop a scientific argument.

embeddable.prompt: Claim: Describe how the two plates in Tectonic Explorer interacted when you set up the model to form a sea like the Red Sea.

pages.name: What's happening in Southern California?
pages.text:
Southern California has many fault lines along which earthquakes are common. The picture shows a lettuce field in El Centro, California (near the border with Mexico) that shifted after an earthquake.

NOAA/NGDC, University of Colorado at Boulder

In the case study on this page, you will:

Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies in Southern California from Seismic Explorer.

Set up a model in Tectonic Explorer to show how the faults in Southern California formed.

Develop a scientific argument about how the Tectonic Explorer model explains the faults in Southern California.

embeddable.content:
Collect data on earthquake and volcano locations and frequencies.

The Seismic Explorer model is zoomed in to southern California.

Tectonic plate names are shown. To see the names of the plates, you will need to zoom out.

If you lose your place, you can click on the globe icon to reset the view. 

Use the Data type menu to show earthquakes and volcanoes along the west coast of California. To show earthquakes, check the Earthquakes box, and press the Play button.

The pin on the map shows the location of El Centro, California.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Using Seismic Explorer, are there volcanoes in Southern California?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Based on Seismic Explorer, what types of earthquakes occur most frequently in Southern California?

choices.prompt: Are you sure? The earthquakes are shallow, but very few are larger than 7.0 magnitude.
Correct! Most of the earthquakes that occur in Southern California are small and shallow. There are some larger earthquakes, too, but they are much more rare.
Are you sure? Check the key to see how earthquake depth is shown.
Are you sure? Check the key to see how earthquake depth is shown.

embeddable.content:
Set up a model.

Use the Tectonic Explorer model to determine how the North American and Pacific plates move at Southern California.

The model is set up with two plates.

You will need to draw continents, assign forces to each plate, and adjust plate densities to create a feature like southern California.
Develop a scientific argument.

pages.name: Revisiting the Nazca-South American plate interactions
pages.text:
Earlier in this activity, you made a prediction about what happens at the boundary between the South American plate and the African plate, based on what you know about the interactions between the Nazca plate and the South American plate.

The plate boundary map is shown below, with the Nazca-South American plate boundary highlighted.

embeddable.content: Set up Tectonic Explorer to create a feature like the Andes Mountains, which are located at the boundary of the Nazca and South American plates.

embeddable.prompt:
When you have formed a feature like the Andes Mountains, pause Tectonic Explorer and rotate the planet.
Take a snapshot of the other side of the plate boundary.
Describe how the plates move relative to each other on the other side of the planet.
Based on what you have learned in the past two activities, describe how you think the Nazca plate moves relative to the Pacific plate (at the boundary marked A on the map).

embeddable.credit: Based on United States Geological Survey

pages.name: Making connections
pages.text:
You have discovered that tectonic plates can move in three basic directions – towards each other, away from each other, or past each other.

        • When two plates move towards each other, the plate boundary between them is called a convergent boundary.
        • When two plates move away from each other, the plate boundary between them is called a divergent boundary.
        • When two plates move past each other, the plate boundary between them is called a transform boundary.

The types of boundaries are shown in the picture below, from the United States Geological Survey (USGS).

By Jose F. Vigil. USGS - [1], Public Domain, Link

Seismic Explorer is zoomed in to show the Nazca plate. Plate names are labeled on the map. Colors along the edges of the plates  show the types of plate boundaries at each edge. Learn more about the plate boundaries by looking at the Key in Seismic Explorer.

embeddable.prompt: Describe the plate interactions that occur at the boundaries of the Nazca plate. Use the plate names in your description.
What happens on the opposite side of a convergent boundary?

embeddable.hint: Earth has more than two plates, unlike the Tectonic Explorer model that you've been experimenting with!
embeddable.prompt: Why do you think that there are transform boundaries (pink color) within the divergent boundary (aqua color) at the western edge of the Nazca plate?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will explore complicated plate interactions and the mechanisms of plate motion.

 

Thumbnail image: By The original uploader was Harroschmeling at German Wikipedia - Transferred from de.wikipedia to Commons., CC BY-SA 3.0, Link
activities.name: What drives plate motion?

pages.name: Earth's complicated surface
pages.text:
So far, the Tectonic Explorer model you have used has been limited to two plates. Earth has eight major plates, ten minor plates, and dozens of microplates.

What features result from more complicated plate interactions?

The Tectonic Explorer model below has five tectonic plates and six landmasses. (Tectonic Explorer has a limited number of plates because of the computational complexity involved.)

Press the Start button to run the model. Watch what happens to the positions of the landmasses and oceans over time. Rotate the planet to observe what happens on all sides. You can use the latitude and longitude lines (see the Menu) to help you keep track of movements.

Can you predict where the continents will end up?

embeddable.prompt:
The plate boundaries are not highlighted in this model.


How can you tell where the plate boundaries are without having them highlighted?
Based on the Tectonic Explorer model, how can the motion of one plate affect the movement of an unconnected plate on the other side of the planet?

embeddable.content:
In Activity 1, you explored paleogeographic maps of Earth, observing how the continents were joined into a megacontinent and then broke up to move into their present-day locations.

This model, even though it has only five tectonic plates, showed continents joining together and breaking apart over time.

embeddable.prompt:
Did you find it easy or difficult to predict what would happen (how the landmasses and oceans would change) in this model?

Explain what made it easy or difficult to make predictions.

pages.name: Where on Earth?
pages.text:
The Tectonic Explorer model is set up the same as on page 1. When you start the model, you will see that the center of each plate is labeled with a number. (You may have to rotate the planet to see the number on the plate.)

Which boundaries on Earth are similar to the boundaries shown in Tectonic Explorer?

Use Seismic Explorer to find similar boundary types on Earth. Plate names are shown.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which boundary on Earth is most similar to the boundary between plate 4 and plate 3?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What type of boundary is most likely to occur on the other side of the plate boundary between plate 4 and plate 3?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Claim: Which boundary on Earth is most similar to the plate boundary between plate 4 and plate 5?
Explanation: Explain your answer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Certainty Rating: How certain are you about your claim based on your explanation?
Certainty Rationale: Explain what influenced your certainty rating.

pages.name: Deep Earth
pages.text:
In Activities 2 and 3, you explored how plate interactions at plate boundaries (convergent, divergent, and transform) resulted in some of Earth's most prominent features – great mountain ranges, deep ocean trenches, and mid-ocean ridges. You used data from Seismic Explorer to map earthquakes and volcanoes along the three types of plate boundaries.

Now that you know how plate interactions formed Earth as we know it today, it's time to explore the question of why tectonic plates move.

The diagram shows a cross section of Earth's structure. The crust lies atop the mantle, which is solid but less rigid, and can slowly flow. The mantle flows over millions of years, as it moves in response to heating from the core.

Concord Consortium

Hot magma rises towards the surface because it is hot and less dense than its surroundings. As the magma cools, it sinks back towards Earth's center.

The video further explains the forces that drive plate tectonics.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What happens at the core-mantle boundary?

choices.choice: Mantle rock is heated and rises.
Mantle rock is heated and sinks.
Mantle rock is cooled and rises.
Mantle rock is cooled and sinks.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
What happens when the mantle rock at the mantle-lithosphere boundary cools?

The mantle rock

embeddable.content:
This pattern of heated rock rising and cooling rock sinking is known as a convection current.

  • When a material is heated, it expands, making it less dense.
  • When a material is cooled, it contracts, making it more dense.

embeddable.prompt: Explain how gravitational forces cause tectonic plates to move.
How does the cooling of oceanic crust cause tectonic plates to move?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What surface features occur when magma rises towards Earth's surface? (Select all that apply.)

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: What surface features occur when magma sinks towards Earth's core? (Select all that apply.)

embeddable.content: Seismic Explorer shows the plate boundaries on Earth.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which part of the mantle convection process is likely to be occurring at the boundary between the Somali plate and the Australian plate?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which part of the mantle convection process is likely occurring at the boundary between the Nazca plate and the South American plate?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.caption: What are the forces that drive plate tectonics?

activities.description:
In this activity, you will use data to make predictions about future Earth.

Thumbnail image: By NASA - http://sideshow.jpl.nasa.gov/mbh/all/images/global.jpg, Public Domain, Link
activities.name: What will Earth look like in the future?

pages.name: Earth now
pages.text:
As you have gone through the first four activities of this sequence, you have learned that Earth has changed over the past 3 billion years. Earth's continents were not always in the places we find them today.

What will happen in the future? Where will the continents be 100 million years from today? We can answer questions about the past because we have evidence from the present-day locations of mountain ranges.

What evidence is there to be able to predict the future?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which type(s) of plate boundary is/are associated with chains of volcanoes?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Which type of plate boundary is associated with deep earthquakes?

embeddable.content:
Press the play button to show earthquakes in Seismic Explorer, and then make a cross section across South America.

Remember that your cross section should be perpendicular to the plate boundary!

embeddable.prompt:
Based on your cross section of South America, describe how the plates are moving at that plate boundary.

Use plate names in your description.

pages.name: Rates of plate motion
pages.sidebar:
GPS (Global Positioning System) station data provide information about how points on Earth are moving relative to each other. This is how scientists measure the direction and distance that tectonic plates move.

How does GPS work?

A system of satellites in orbit around Earth continuously broadcast signals about the time and their location. Receivers on Earth, like the ones in cell phones, receive these signals from multiple satellites. Processors within the receivers use the signals from many satellites to compute the precise location of the receiver on Earth.

GPS receivers have been placed in many places on Earth's surface, allowing geoscientists to monitor very small movements of Earth's crust. (Because GPS also gives elevation location, geoscientists can use the data to monitor swelling around volcanoes, allowing them to predict when an eruption might occur.)

The image below, a time series of GPS readings from GPS receivers around the world, show how various locations are moving relative to each other. The yellow lines show the horizontal velocities of each of the stations (shown by green pins). If a station has not moved much, the yellow line is short. If the station has moved a lot, the yellow line is long.

NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology GPS Time Series

Analyzing this data allows geoscientists to map how fast plates are moving at their boundaries.
pages.text:
Earthquake and volcano data provide evidence as to where plate boundaries are today, and cross sections of earthquakes can tell us the direction of plate movement at convergent boundaries.

Plate movement data is shown in Seismic Explorer. Click on the i for information about how fast the plates are moving along various boundaries.

Use Seismic Explorer to observe the rates and directions of plate motion.

embeddable.hint: To see continent names, check the box next to Continent and ocean names in the Data type menu.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt:
Based on the plate movement data in Seismic Explorer, how are North America and Asia moving relative to each other?

North America and Asia are
Explain your answer.
Describe the geological surface features that provide evidence of how North America and Asia are moving relative to each other.

embeddable.hint: Is the planet changing size (growing or shrinking)?
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Without using any of the numbers in Seismic Explorer, do you think that the rate of motion for all convergent plate boundaries is equal the to rate of motion for all divergent plate boundaries for the entire planet?
Explain your answer.
How do you think scientists can predict what Earth might look like in the future?

embeddable.content:
Did you ever wonder: how do scientists measure plate movement?


GPS (Global Positioning System) station data provide information about how points on Earth are moving relative to each other. This is how scientists measure the direction and distance that tectonic plates move.

How does GPS work?

A system of satellites in orbit around Earth continuously broadcast signals about the time and their location. Receivers on Earth, like the ones in cell phones, receive these signals from multiple satellites. Processors within the receivers use the signals from many satellites to compute the precise location of the receiver on Earth.

GPS receivers have been placed in many places on Earth's surface, allowing geoscientists to monitor very small movements of Earth's crust. (Because GPS also gives elevation location, geoscientists can use the data to monitor swelling around volcanoes, allowing them to predict when an eruption might occur.)

The image below, a time series of GPS readings from GPS receivers around the world, show how various locations are moving relative to each other. The yellow lines show the horizontal velocities of each of the stations (shown by green pins). If a station has not moved much, the yellow line is short. If the station has moved a lot, the yellow line is long.

NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology GPS Time Series

Analyzing this data allows geoscientists to map how fast plates are moving at their boundaries.

pages.name: Why are the Appalachian Mountains there?
pages.text:
The Appalachian Mountains can be found along the east coast of North America.

The photo shows the view looking southwest from the observation tower atop Mount Mitchell in North Carolina. Mount Mitchell is the highest point in the Appalachians and the highest peak in North America east of the Mississippi River.

By Ken Thomas - KenThomas.us(personal website of photographer), Public Domain, Link

Seismic Explorer is zoomed in to show the Appalachian Mountain chain. The relief map view shows the different elevations in different colors. The brown colors indicate the locations of the mountains along the Appalachian chain.

Why are the Appalachian Mountains there? How did they form?

embeddable.hint: Use the Data type menu to show current plate boundaries.
embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: Is there a plate boundary near the Appalachian Mountains today?

embeddable.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddable.prompt: In the past, do you think that there was there a plate boundary located near where the Appalachian Mountains are?
Explain your answer.

embeddable.content:
Use Seismic Explorer to explore evidence that the Atlantic Ocean was closed about 480 million years ago.

Use Tectonic Explorer to run experiments to test your ideas about why the Appalachian Mountains are located where they are.

embeddable.hint:
Think about both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. The Appalachian Mountains are found on the eastern side of the Atlantic Ocean.
Is there evidence on the western side of the Atlantic Ocean?
embeddable.prompt: Based on your experiments with Tectonic Explorer and the data in Seismic Explorer, what is the evidence for the Atlantic Ocean having closed around 480 million years ago?

pages.name: What is the future of East Africa?
pages.text:
In the snapshot below, from Seismic Explorer, a white arrow points at the boundary between the African and Somali plates.



Use this image and the models (Seismic Explorer and Tectonic Explorer) to predict what the region that is now Eastern Africa will look like in 200 million years.
